newsitem.title: USA: BankBoston cites non-interest income in Q4.
newsitem.headline: BankBoston cites non-interest income in Q4.

text.p: BankBoston Corp said income in several non-interest business grew at double digit rates in the fourth quarter despite divestitures, buoying overall results.
Overall, BankBoston said net income rose 12 percent from a year ago to $201.5 million while per-share earnings rose 15 percent from a year ago to $1.24 diluted..
William Shea, vice chairman and chief financial officer, said contributors to non-interest income included private equity investing, asset management, Latin American business and capital markets.

Charles Gifford, chief executive, said the the company expects to have a Section 20 subsidiary fully operational "very shortly." Secton 20 subsidiaries under U.S. law allow bank holding companies to engage in corporate debt and securities dealing subject to certain limitations.

Gifford said the company's Latin American franchise continues to grow rapidly, particularly in the fee-based business area. He eaid the company will actively seek to expand its distribution network in the region seeking to leverage existing synergies with domestic and global businesses.

Overall, non-interest income in the fourth quarter totaled $340 million versus $367 million a year ago. A decrease in financial service feels to $147 million from $164 million reflected the sale of the company's mortgage banking subsidiary.

Fourth-quarter 1996 results included a gain of $47 million from the sale of 20 branches, and a charge of $25 million from the transfer of $400 million of commercial real estate laons into a hold-for-sale account. BankBoston said the transfer was part of its balance sheet management program.

Net interest revenue in the fourth-quarter before the provision for credit losses rose to $611.2 million from $572.9 million a year ago. The provision for credit losses was $60.0 million versus $81.0 million.
The net interest margin was 4.47 percent versus 4.50 percent.
